lexUnit.name: gossip.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: casual conversation or unsubstantiated reports about other people

sentence.text: Perhaps these techniques have that irresistible fascination of overhearing gossip about oneself .
The locals are already trading gossip about the hundreds of youngsters packing the beach .

The story rocketed around Hollywood and outgunned all the gossip of crawling up drainpipes , being visited in his dressing room by naked ladies , drinking day and night , smashing his head against a wall .
To refute any groundless gossip on so important a subject I consider it necessary to inform you that I have no intention of doing so immediately .
During the latter part of 1988 , the music papers were full of gossip about the band joining forces with a major label .
All week long , the Hollywood gossip about this case was of drugs , mysticism and off-beat sex , and for once there may be more truth than fantasy in the flashy talk of the town . "
They exchanged banter and gossip about old friends , new acquaintances , and fresh scandals .
` I know who John Thaw is of course , " he said , ` but I have never heard any gossip about him buying a house here .
And if she had heard nothing of the gossip about his private life before she accepted him , certain ladies he had discarded , both married and single , took care that she overheard quite a lot now .
There is without a shadow of doubt some very nasty gossip about me now sludging its filthy way through the intestines of the society I know and have come to despise .
I 'll tell them malicious gossip about the rest of the club and I 'll become a kind of mascot .
` Joe heard the gossip about you and me and this is his revenge . "
There was a bar on the premises , and on a YCs night it would be filled with the laughter and gossip of young drinkers , some below the legal age of drinking .

With its sights set against the established social and political order , it was further estranged from those newspapers which were able to participate in the reporting and gossip of metropolitan politics .
After all , what was the gossip of princes and their doxies to a priest ?
One day Sam heard an interesting piece of gossip from some of the adult workers .
My act , as always , is an intimate gossip with the audience -- and this made it very tricky .
Unlike the trainees , established dealers pick up market gossip with a lightning instinct .
The new pop stars -- self-conscious frauds , tackily glamorous like Boy George -- fed a revival of old-fashioned pop gossip , a staple now of the Sun and the Mirror .
For the remainder of the meal , they chatted politely about business and exchanged city gossip .
Women , especially mothers , are often guilty of birth gossip , and unwittingly create fear in the minds of first-time mothers .
She 'd grown up into a beautiful fair girl , and every lad in the county had his eye on her , as Billy knew from all the women 's gossip .
There are intimate ideological connections between women 's gossip on the one hand and sorcery and witchcraft on the other .
He continued to gabble away under his breath and the ladies returned to their gossip .
Even if he were willing to ply so late , I did not feel equal to his gossip , or that of the troops who might be making their way back .
` Never mind your gossip now , Thomas , " exhorted their hostess .
Father Devine went on to speak of his admiration for Shakespeare , but had no fresh gossip about the Bard .
He was off-hand with her , even when she recounted the gossip about Meredith being thrown out of his lodgings .

Their conversation became more relaxed , drifting from their backgrounds to their jobs to increasingly indiscreet gossip about their colleagues , as the alcohol turned them from new acquaintances into old and trusted friends .
Moreover there was gossip about the two which disgusted me .
